00005 // This example demonstrates loading, running and scripting a very simple NaCl
00006 // module.  To load the NaCl module, the browser first looks for the
00007 // CreateModule() factory method (ad the end of this file).  It calls
00008 // CreateModule() once to load the module code from your .nexe.  After the
00009 // .nexe code is loaded, CreateModule() is not called again.
00010 //
00011 // Once the .nexe code is loaded, the browser than calls the CreateInstance()
00012 // method on the object returned by CreateModule().  It calls CreateInstance()
00013 // each time it encounters an <embed> tag that references your NaCl module.
00014 //
00015 // When the browser encounters JavaScript that references your NaCl module, it
00016 // calls the GetInstanceObject() method on the object returned from
00017 // CreateInstance().  In this example, the returned object is a subclass of
00018 // ScriptableObject, which handles the scripting support.
00019 
00020 #include <ppapi/cpp/instance.h>
00021 #include <ppapi/cpp/module.h>
00022 #include <ppapi/cpp/scriptable_object.h>
00023 #include <ppapi/cpp/var.h>
00024 
00025 // These are the method names as JavaScript sees them.
00026 namespace {
00027 const char* kHelloWorldMethodId = "helloWorld";
00028 const char* kFortyTwoMethodId = "fortyTwo";
00029 
00030 // This is the module's function that does the work to compute the value 42.
00031 // The ScriptableObject that called this function then returns the result back
00032 // to the browser as a JavaScript value.
00033 int32_t FortyTwo() {
00034   return 42;
00035 }
00036 
00037 // This function returns a pointer to some constant memory holding the string
00038 // "hello, world.".  The ScriptableObject that called this function then returns
00039 // the result back to the browser as a JavaScript value
00040 std::string HelloWorld() {
00041   const char *msg = "hello, world.";
00042   return msg;
00043 }
00044 }  // namespace
00045 
00046 // This class exposes the scripting interface for this NaCl module.  The
00047 // HasMethod method is called by the browser when executing a method call on
00048 // the |helloWorld| object (see, e.g. the helloWorld() function in
00049 // hello_world.html).  The name of the JavaScript function (e.g. "fortyTwo") is
00050 // passed in the |method| paramter as a string pp::Var.  If HasMethod()
00051 // returns |true|, then the browser will call the Call() method to actually
00052 // invoke the method.
00053 class HelloWorldScriptableObject : public pp::ScriptableObject {
00054  public:
00055   // Return |true| if |method| is one of the exposed method names.
00056   virtual bool HasMethod(const pp::Var& method, pp::Var* exception);
00057 
00058   // Invoke the function associated with |method|.  The argument list passed in
00059   // via JavaScript is marshaled into a vector of pp::Vars.  None of the
00060   // functions in this example take arguments, so this vector is always empty.
00061   virtual pp::Var Call(const pp::Var& method,
00062                        const std::vector<pp::Var>& args,
00063                        pp::Var* exception);
00064 };
00065 
00066 bool HelloWorldScriptableObject::HasMethod(const pp::Var& method,
00067                                            pp::Var* exception) {
00068   if (!method.is_string()) {
00069     return false;
00070   }
00071   std::string method_name = method.AsString();
00072   bool has_method = method_name == kHelloWorldMethodId ||
00073       method_name == kFortyTwoMethodId;
00074   return has_method;
00075 }
00076 
00077 pp::Var HelloWorldScriptableObject::Call(const pp::Var& method,
00078                                          const std::vector<pp::Var>& args,
00079                                          pp::Var* exception) {
00080   if (!method.is_string()) {
00081     return pp::Var();
00082   }
00083   std::string method_name = method.AsString();
00084   if (method_name == kHelloWorldMethodId)
00085     return pp::Var(HelloWorld());
00086   else if (method_name == kFortyTwoMethodId)
00087     return pp::Var(FortyTwo());
00088   return pp::Var();
00089 }
00090 
00091 // The Instance class.  One of these exists for each instance of your NaCl
00092 // module on the web page.  The browser will ask the Module object to create
00093 // a new Instance for each occurence of the <embed> tag that has these
00094 // attributes:
00095 //     type="application/x-ppapi-nacl-srpc"
00096 //     nexes="ARM: hello_world_arm.nexe
00097 //            ..."
00098 // The Instance can return a ScriptableObject representing itself.  When the
00099 // browser encounters JavaScript that wants to access the Instance, it calls
00100 // the GetInstanceObject() method.  All the scripting work is done though
00101 // the returned ScriptableObject.
00102 class HelloWorldInstance : public pp::Instance {
00103  public:
00104   HelloWorldInstance(PP_Instance instance) : pp::Instance(instance) {}
00105   virtual ~HelloWorldInstance() {}
00106 
00107   // The pp::Var takes over ownership of the HelloWorldScriptableObject.
00108   virtual pp::Var GetInstanceObject() {
00109     HelloWorldScriptableObject* hw_object = new HelloWorldScriptableObject();
00110     return pp::Var(hw_object);
00111   }
00112 };
00113 
00114 // The Module class.  The browser calls the CreateInstance() method to create
00115 // an instance of you NaCl module on the web page.  The browser creates a new
00116 // instance for each <embed> tag with type="application/x-ppapi-nacl-srpc".
00117 class HelloWorldModule : public pp::Module {
00118  public:
00119   HelloWorldModule() : pp::Module() {}
00120   virtual ~HelloWorldModule() {}
00121 
00122   // Create and return a HelloWorldInstance object.
00123   virtual pp::Instance* CreateInstance(PP_Instance instance) {
00124     return new HelloWorldInstance(instance);
00125   }
00126 };
00127 
00128 // Factory function called by the browser when the module is first loaded.
00129 // The browser keeps a singleton of this module.  It calls the
00130 // CreateInstance() method on the object you return to make instances.  There
00131 // is one instance per <embed> tag on the page.  This is the main binding
00132 // point for your NaCl module with the browser.
00133 namespace pp {
00134 Module* CreateModule() {
00135   return new HelloWorldModule();
00136 }
00137 }  // namespace pp
